sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Angiography, Pulmonary or Arch study used alone: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 30 mL IV injection; range, 10 to 56 mL
  • Aortography: (Hypaque(TM)-76 or RenoCal-76(R)) 15 to 40 mL as a single rapid IV injection into the aorta by translumbar or retrograde (brachial) catheter; repeated if indicated; MAX total dose 160 mL
  • Arteriography, Aorto-iliac runoff and peripheral: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 20 to 40 mL single dose IV injection, depending on the site of placements (eg; aorta-iliac runoff, iliofemoral, femoral), repeated up to 3 times
  • Arteriography, Aorto-iliac runoff and peripheral: (Renografin(R)-60 or Renocal-76(R)) 20 to 40 mL single dose, rapidly injected into the femoral or subclavian artery by PERCUTANEOUS or operative method to visualize an entire extremity; 10 to 20 mL to visualize upper or lower half of the extremity
  • Arteriography, Intravenous digital: (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 30 to 60 mL or approximately 0.5 to 1 mL/kg per bolus injection by IV digital technique into a peripheral vein by mechanical injection or rapid manual injection; administered as a rate of 7.5 mL/second to 30 mL/second using a pressure injector; MAX total volume 200 mL with multiple bolus injections
  • Arteriography, Selective visceral: (Hypaque(TM)-76, celiac axis, 30 to 40 mL with subselective arteriography of its branches; hepatic, 25 mL (range, 15 to 30 mL); mesenteric, 30 mL (range, 20 to 40 mL); splenic, 20 mL (range, 20 to 50 mL)
  • Arteriography, Selective visceral: (Hypaque(TM)-76, superior mesenteric) 30 mL (range, 20 to 40 mL); MAX total dose 175 mL
  • Arteriography, Selective visceral: (Renocal-76(R), celiac axis and its branches, superior mesenteric artery, or inferior mesenteric artery, 30 to 50 mL injected into the appropriate visceral artery via femoral artery catheterization; repeated as necessary; MAX total dose 250 mL
  • Arthrography: (Rengrafin(R)-60) knee, 5 to 15 mL injection; shoulder or hip, 5 to 10 mL injection; other joints, 1 to 4 mL injection
  • Cardiac ventriculography: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 45 mL as a single IV injection; range, 40 to 50 mL; repeated as necessary; MAX total dose 225 mL if combined with selective coronary arteriography
  • Cardiac ventriculography, Left heart - Coronary angiography, Selective: (Renocal-76(R)) 35 to 50 mL injected into the left ventricle; repeated as necessary; MAX total dose for the combined procedures 200 mL
  • CAT scan - whole body, Contrast enhancement: (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 50 to 125 mL rapid IV bolus administration
  • CAT scan - whole body, Contrast enhancement: (Rengrafin(R)-60) 100 mL rapid IV bolus injection (within approximately 1 minute)
  • Cervical discography: (Rengrafin(R)-60) up to 0.5 mL injected slowly; MAX 2 mL into any one disk
  • Coronary angiography, Selective: (Renocal-76(R)) 4 to 10 mL injected into a coronary artery; repeated as necessary; MAX total dose 150 mL
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 50 to 125 mL IV
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement: (Rengrafin(R)-60) 50 to 150 mL IV
  • Head angiography: (Renograpfin(R)) 10 mL rapidly injected by PERCUTANEOUS or operative method; repeated as indicated
  • Intraoperative cholangiogram: (Renografin(R)-60) 10 to 25 mL IV instilled slowly through the stump of the cystic duct or directly into the choledochal lumen, repeated if needed
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 20 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; range, 20 to 40 mL
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (Renografin(R)-60) 25 mL direct IV injection (range, 25 to 50 mL) OR 1 mL/pound of body weight diluted with equal volume of Sterile water for injection by drip infusion (for pyelography) at a rate of 40 mL/min
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: IV doses may be divided and used IM, administered bilaterally into the gluteal muscles.
  • Lumbar discography: (Rengrafin(R)-60) 1 or 2 mL injected slowly; MAX 2 mL into any one disk
  • Nephrotomogram: (Renocal-76(R)) 100 mL by rapid bolus IV injection over an interval of up to 4 min or by IV infusion up to 15 min, depending on the volume of the solution
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram: (Rengrafin(R)-60) 20 to 40 mL slowly injected into the biliary duct under very slight pressure; if a duct is not located, small doses of 1 to 2 mL injected into the liver as the needle is gradually withdrawn, until a duct is visualized by x-ray
  • Postoperative cholangiography - T tube cholangiogram: (Rengrafin(R)-60) 10 to 25 mL injected through an in-place T-tube, performed 8 to 10 days after operation
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Gastrografin(R)) 30 to 90 mL (11 to 33 g iodine) ORALLY
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Gastrografin(R)) 240 mL (88 g iodine) in 1000 mL of tap water (dilution) RECTALLY
  • Renal arteriography, Selective: (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 8 mL (range 5 to 10 mL) single dose injected into either or both renal arteries via femoral artery catheterization, repeated up to 3 times
  • Splenoportogram by splenic arteriography: (Rengrafin(R)-60) approximately 20 to 25 mL injected rapidly after radiologic location and puncture of the spleen
  • Tomographic imaging: (Gastrografin(R)) 240 mL ORALLY of diluted solution (25 mL (9.17 g iodine) in 1 L of tap water), 15 to 30 minutes before imaging; may also use less diluted solutions (up to 77 mL (28.26 g iodine) in 1 L of tap water)
  • Venography, Central, inferior or superior vena cava: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 40 to 50 mL IV injection, repeated up to 2 times
  • Venography, Peripheral: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 40 mL single dose IV injection; range, 40 to 60 mL
  • Venography, Peripheral: (Renografin-60) 10 mL per upper extremity as a single dose by rapid PERCUTANEOUS injection into any convenient superficial vein of the forearm or hand
  • Venography, Peripheral: (Renografin-60) 20 to 40 mL per lower extremity; injected rapidly into a superficial vein on the lateral side of the foot; MAX 100 mL per lower extremity
  • Venography, Peripheral: (Renografin-60) 50 mL or more to visualize the iliac vein, extensive varicosities or large veins
  • Venography, Renal: (Hypaque(TM)-76) a single dose of 20 to 40 mL IV injection

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Angiocardiography, Pediatric: (5 to 10 years of age) (Renocal-76(R)) a single dose of 20 to 30 mL rapidly injected into a large peripheral vein or by direct catheterization of the heart; doses of up to a total of 100 mL have been administered safely
  • Angiocardiography, Pediatric: (younger than 5 years) (Renocal-76(R)) a single dose of 10 to 20 mL rapidly injected into a large peripheral vein or by direct catheterization of the heart
  • Angiography, Pulmonary or Arch study used alone: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 0.3 to 0.9 mL/kg IV injection; MAX total dose 1 mL/kg
  • Aortography: (16 years or older) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or RenoCal-76(R)) 15 to 40 mL as a single rapid IV injection into the aorta by translumbar or retrograde (brachial) catheter; repeated if indicated; MAX total dose 160 mL
  • Aortography: (younger than 16 years) (Hypaque(TM)-76) 0.3 to 0.9 mL/kg, as a single rapid IV injection into the aorta by translumbar or retrograde (brachial) catheter; repeated if necessary; MAX total dose 1 mL/kg
  • Arthrography: (Rengrafin(R)-60) proportionally less than adult doses (knee, 5 to 15 mL injection; shoulder or hip, 5 to 10 mL injection; other joints, 1 to 4 mL injection)
  • Cardiac ventriculography: (Hypaque(TM)-76) 0.2 to 0.3 mL/kg as a single IV injection; MAX total dose 50 mL
  • CAT scan - whole body, Contrast enhancement: proportionally less than adult doses, depending on age and weight
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement: proportionally less than adult doses, depending on age and weight
  • Head angiography: (Renograpfin(R)) children require less than the 10 mL adult dose rapidly injected by PERCUTANEOUS or operative method, use dose in proportion to weight
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (younger than 6 months) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 4 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 5 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (6 to 12 months of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 6 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 8 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (1 to 2 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 8 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 10 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (2 to 5 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 10 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 12 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (5 to 7 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 12 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 15 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (8 to 10 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 14 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 18 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (11 to 15 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 16 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 20 mL IV injection
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (16 years or older) (Hypaque(TM)-76 or Renocal-76(R)) 20 mL INTRAVASCULAR by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; (Renografin(R)-60) 25 to 50 mL IV injection; (Renocal-76(R)) 20 to 40 mL
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: IV doses may be divided and used IM, administered bilaterally into the gluteal muscles.
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (5 to 10 years) (Gastrografin(R)) 60 mL (22 g iodine) ORALLY, may be diluted 1:1 with water, carbonated drinks, milk, or mineral oil
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (younger than 5 years) (Gastrografin(R)) 30 mL (11 g iodine) ORALLY, may be diluted 1:1 with water, carbonated drinks, milk, or mineral oil
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (less than 10 kg) (Gastrografin(R)) 1 part contrast agents in 3 parts water dilution ORALLY
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (5 years or older) (Gastrografin(R)) 90 mL (33 g iodine) in 500 mL of tap water (dilution) RECTALLY
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (younger than 5 years) (Gastrografin(R)) a 1:5 dilution in tap water RECTALLY

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• (elderly cachectic patients) (Gastrografin(R)) a 1:1 dilution of contrast agent, with water, carbonated drinks, milk, or mineral oil ORALLY
  • (debilitated children) Gastrografin(R)) 1 part contrast agent in 3 parts water dilution ORALLY
  • (dehydrated and/or debilitated adults) may use pediatric doses 30 to 60 mL (11 to 22 g iodine) ORALLY.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Angiocardiography, Pediatric
  • Angiography, Pulmonary or Arch study used alone
  • Aortography
  • Arteriography, Aorto-iliac runoff and peripheral
  • Arteriography, Intravenous digital
  • Arteriography, Selective visceral
  • Arthrography
  • Cardiac ventriculography
  • Cardiac ventriculography, Left heart - Coronary angiography, Selective
  • CAT scan - whole body, Contrast enhancement
  • Cervical discography
  • Coronary angiography, Selective
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement
  • Head angiography
  • Intraoperative cholangiogram
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography
  • Lumbar discography
  • Nephrotomogram
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram
  • Postoperative cholangiography - T tube cholangiogram
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract
  • Renal arteriography, Selective
  • Splenoportogram by splenic arteriography
  • Tomographic imaging
  • Venography, Central, inferior or superior vena cava
  • Venography, Peripheral
  • Venography, Renal

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• anuria; urography and nephrotomography are contraindicated (injection)
  • coagulation defect or thrombocytopenia; percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is contraindicated with Renografin(R)-60
  • dehydrated azotemic patients; urography and large-dose vascular procedures are contraindicated with HYPAQUE(TM)-76
  • epidural administration (injection)
  • hypersensitivity to diatrizoic acid salts (injection)
  • intrathecal procedures (injection)
  • prothrombin time below 50%; use of Renografin(R)-60 with percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is contraindicated
  • splenectomy is contraindicated; splenoportography should not be performed (Renografin(R)-60)
  • when used as recommended, there are no specific contraindications for administration of oral solution

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• abdominal compression; increased risk of neurologic complications (including paraplegia) when HYPAQUE(TM)-76 is administered with aortography
  • administration into subarachnoid space; even small amounts may cause convulsions and death (intravenous)
  • angiography, cerebral or spinal; use of HYPAQUE(TM)-76 is not recommended
  • aortic-iliac or femoral artery bed obstruction; increased risk of neurologic complications (including paraplegia) when HYPAQUE(TM)-76 is administered with aortography
  • aortic circulation, slowed; increased risk of muscle spasm when HYPAQUE(TM)-76 is administered with aortography
  • arterial hypertension, severe; increased risk when Renografin(R)-60 is administered with cerebral angiography
  • arteriosclerosis, advanced; risk when Renografin(R)-60 is administered with cerebral angiography
  • arteriosclerosis, severe generalized; risk when RenoCal-76(R) is administered with selective visceral arteriography
  • ascending infection with severe ischemia; risk associated with HYPAQUE(TM)-76 administration during peripheral angiography
  • blood pressure, low or high; increased risk of neurologic complications (including paraplegia) with HYPAQUE(TM)-76 administration during aortography
  • brain metastases; increased risk of seizures when high doses of ionic contrast media are given during CT scan
  • bronchial asthma or allergy, personal or family history; increased risk of drug hypersensitivity reaction
  • cardiac decompensation; increased risk with cerebral angiography (Renografin(R)-60)
  • cerebral embolism, recent; increased risk with cerebral angiography (Renografin(R)-60)
  • concomitant chelating agent; may increase risk of toxicity with coronary angiography (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • concomitant general anesthesia; may increase risk of adverse effects due to reduced cardiac output and increased duration of contrast agent exposure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • concomitant hepatic and renal disease, severe; risk with urography and nephrotomography (injection)
  • concomitant vasopressor use; increased risk of neurologic complications, including paraplegia, with aortography administration (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • conditions that promote hyperacidity (such as stress, fasting, or emotional upset); possible precipitation of contrast media may be interpreted radiologically as an anatomical abnormality (oral)
  • congestive heart failure; risk with drip infusion pyelography due to increased osmotic load (injection)
  • debilitated, severely; risk with cerebral angiography, and risk of thrombosis with percutaneous administration techniques (injection)
  • diabetes; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • diabetes with diabetic neuropathy; risk of acute renal failure following urographic procedures (injection)
  • dilution to less than 16.5% diatrizoate salts; hypertonic solution may cause hypervolemia (oral, rectal)
  • elderly patients; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • elderly patients with renal disease, or other susceptible nondiabetic patients; risk of acute renal failure following urographic procedures (injection)
  • electrolyte imbalances; increased risk of shock caused by hypertonic preparations, especially in young or debilitated children and elderly cachectic patients (oral, rectal)
  • esophagotracheal fistula; accidental aspiration may cause serious pulmonary complications, such as pulmonary edema or pneumonitis (oral)
  • extreme age; increased risk with cerebral angiography (Renografin(R)-60)
  • goiter, multinodular; increased hormone synthesis may result in hyperthyroidism (oral)
  • heart failure, incipient; angiocardiography may aggravate condition (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • hepatic or biliary disorder, known or suspected, who have recently received a cholecystographic contrast agent; possible risk of renal toxicity (injection)
  • hypertension, marked; risk of thrombosis with percutaneous administration techniques (injection)
  • hyperthyroidism; risk of thyroid storm following intravascular use; theoretical risk with oral preparation
  • hypotension; angiocardiography may induce serious arrhythmias (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • infants and young children; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure; increased risk of convulsions, especially with repeated injections (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • infants, cyanotic; angiocardiography may cause apnea, convulsions, cerebral effects, acidosis, and arrhythmias (injection)
  • low-injection sites (L2 to L3); increased risk of neurologic complications, including paraplegia, with aortography (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • multiple myeloma; precipitation of myeloma protein in renal tubules may cause anuria, leading to progressive uremia, renal failure, and death (injection)
  • myocardial infarction, within four weeks; selective coronary arteriography not recommended (RenoCal-76(R))
  • pheochromocytoma, known or suspected; risk of hypertensive crisis (injection)
  • pulmonary emphysema, chronic; risk with angiocardiography (RenoCal-76(R))
  • pulmonary entry by aspiration; may cause serious pulmonary complications, such as pulmonary edema or pneumonitis (oral)
  • pulmonary hypertension; angiocardiography may cause an increase in pulmonary artery blood pressure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • pulmonary vascular beds, decreased or obliterated; angiocardiography may cause an increase in pulmonary artery blood pressure (especially in infants weighing less than 7 kg) (injection)
  • renal failure, advanced; preparatory partial dehydration with nephrotomography is not recommended (intravenous)
  • renal insufficiency; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • renal transplant; use caution when performing excretory urography immediately following surgery (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • right heart "strain"; normal dosing with angiocardiography may increase risk of adverse drug effects (especially in infants weighing less than 7 kg) (RenoCal-76(R))
  • right ventricular failure; angiocardiography may cause a rise in right ventricular blood pressure (especially in infants weighing less than 7 kg who receive normal drug dosage) (injection)
  • sensitivity to iodine or other contrast agent, history
  • sickle cell disease, homozygous; intravenous or intra-arterial administration may precipitate sickling
  • spinal anesthesia; increased risk of neurologic complications, including paraplegia, with aortography administration (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • subarachnoid hemorrhage; risk of clinical deterioration, including convulsions and death (injection)
  • thromboangiitis obliterans; risk associated with peripheral angiography (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)
  • uremia or severely impaired renal function; risk of impaired visualization with excretion urography (intravenous)
  • vascular disease, advanced; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (HYPAQUE(TM)-76)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Diatrizoate: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Diatrizoate: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Vasodilatation (49%)
  • Dermatologic:Flushing, Injection site pain (about 12%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (6%), Taste sense altered (11%), Vomiting (3%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (5%), Paresthesia (6%)
  • Renal:Hypokalemic nephropathy, Osmotic nephrosis after excretory urography (23%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (2%), Rhinitis (1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest (less than 1%), Shock (0.005%), Thrombophlebitis, Ventricular fibrillation (less than 1%)
  • Dermatologic:Necrosis / ulceration of skin due to extravasation of drug (1%)
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (less than 1%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Renal:Renal failure (less than 1%)
  • Respiratory:Bronchospasm (less than 1%), Pulmonary edema (less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The use of diatrizoate is not based on its pharmacologic properties, but on its distribution and elimination from the body. The iodine content of a contrast media is the most important factor, since this component is responsible for the absorption of radiation and the degree of opacification. The high atomic weight of iodine contributes sufficient x-radiation attenuation to impart radiographic contrast with surrounding tissue. Diagnostic radiopaque agents have few known pharmacological effects.

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Protein binding: 0% to 10% bound to serum albumin

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: (intravenous), less than 2%
  • Renal: (intravenous), 12% within 10 minutes, 38% at 60 minutes, 45% at 3 hours, and 94% to 100% at 24 hours excreted unchanged

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • do NOT administer by intrathecal route
  • solution should be at body temperature when injected; may need to be warmed
  • if crystallization occurs, place the vial in a water bath at 40 to 50 degrees C and shake it gently for 2 to 3 minutes or until solids redissolve; discard the vial if particles still persist
  • solution may be autoclaved once
  • do not contaminate catheters, syringes, needles, and contrast media with glove powder or cotton fibers
  • discard any unused portion
  • (angiography), flush the catheter frequently with heparinized saline solutions; use plastic syringes in place of glass to decrease the likelihood of in vitro clotting.
  • (cervical discography), use 2-needle technique to avoid the rupture of the disk
  • (operative and T-tube cholangiography), inject the agent very slowly to prevent extravasation.
  • (percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), aspirate as much of the contrast agent as possible after the procedure to reduce to potential of bile leakage and peritonitis
  • (splenoportography), avoid manipulations which would prolong the time the needle is in the spleen to avoid subcapsular extravasation of agent and bleeding

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• image quality and diagnostic usefulness
  • vital signs; baseline and then periodically
  • ECG; baseline and then periodically as clinically indicated
  • injection site reactions; frequently for any signs of extravasation
  • renal and hepatic function; baseline and then periodically as clinically indicated
  • signs and symptoms of iodine or other contrast agents sensitivity; during procedure and then for 30 to 60 minutes after the procedure
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis; especially when percutaneous techniques are employed
  • thyroid function tests (T3 resin uptake and total or free thyroxine (T4) assays); at baseline and after procedure as clinically indicated

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Gastrografin
    Oral Solution: (Diatrizoate Meglumine - Diatrizoate Sodium) 66 %-10 %
  • MD-Gastroview
    Oral Solution: (Diatrizoate Meglumine - Diatrizoate Sodium) 66 %-10 %

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness.
  • Instruct patient to rise slowly from a sitting/supine position, as drug may cause hypotension.
  • The injection form of this drug may cause vasodilation, fever, chills, paresthesia, asthenia, nausea, vomiting, cough, and rash.
  • The oral form of this drug may cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, heartburn, diarrhea, rash, itching, and headache.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of thyroid storm (chest pain, tachycardia, dyspnea, fever, anxiety).
  • Instruct patients to be fully hydrated before procedures (with the possible exception of urography).
